Because it is a replacement for Scalia, there will still be strong objections in general from Republicans, no matter what; and with a vocal group of Trump supporters, regardless of the election outcome, it won't be easy to get strong agreement.

It does, though, seem less likely that the senate will move quickly to confirm Garland in a lame duck session.

(no change) While most polling shows that the US Presidential race probably won't be close, I started thinking about DT and his penchant for lawsuits (I believe he has a history of being involved in ~15k; thousands anyway). Since he is inclined to file lawsuits, what are the chances he would not challenge something about the US election? Yes, that is what I suspect. Even if some points related to the election were hard to envision, what would a District Court do? Dismissing something from someone with ~40% of US voters might not have the right optics. I'm guessing that they would bump it up immediately to the relevant Appeals Court. What would they do? Try to deal with it quickly and take a chance that DT would then ask to have the SCOTUS look at it? Again, the optics are complicated and the clock would be ticking. If some challenge were to land with the Supreme Court, would they be satisfied making a decision with only 8 Justices? Timing of this whole fantasy would be tricky, but perhaps McConnell would move to quickly confirm Garland so there would be nine Justices to provide more credibility "for the good of the country." (Thereby having a convenient excuse for his shift.)

Technically, there are two ways for this to happen: in the lame-duck session after the presidential elections and in the two weeks in early 2017 when the new Congress gets in session. The lame-duck session is probably out of question as the Republicans are unlikely to come around to Obama's proposed nomination so quickly (and they always insisted that the new President should propose the appointee :)). The early 2017 session is  more interesting as the Democrats may have a majority in the Senate, but there is simply not much time. So this will happen if (i) the next President is OK with Judge Garland; and (ii) the Democrats want to make a point that it's possible to fill a Supreme Court seat in the last year of a presidency, even though this is not quite the same after the presidential election. Overall, a small chance.

Arizona Senator Jeff Flake said in March 2016 that Garland should not be confirmed unless Hillary Clinton wins the 2016 presidential election. He argued that should Clinton win, Garland should be confirmed in the Senate's lame-duck session because he is less liberal than any nominee Clinton might put forward. After meeting with Garland in April, Flake reiterated this position, saying that confirmation hearings on Garland's nomination should not be taken up until after the election, so that the American people can choose the next president, unless Clinton wins, in which case, "we ought to approve him quickly." Orrin Hatch echoed this sentiment, saying that he was "open to resolving this [Garland's nomination after a Clinton win] in a lame duck."

So just how is the court conducting Business w/o Scalia?
 The U.S. Supreme Court kicked off its busy season, wrapping up its lingering cases over the final three weeks of this term. Most notably, SCOTUS unanimously rejected judgments of U.S. Courts of Appeals in five out of six opinions handed down this week. In the sixth opinion, a 5-4 majority affirmed (and still sent the case back).  
Have you been keeping score at home? Of the 56 opinions issued this term, half have been unanimous. As of June 16, SCOTUS has affirmed the judgment of a case on appeal 25 times, and has either reversed, vacated, sent a case back (remanded), and/or dismissed an appeal in some fashion 39 times. Since Justice Kagan joined the court in 2010, the court has affirmed the judgments of lower courts in 28%-37% of cases during any given term (October-June). The court has 13 outstanding opinions in argued cases remaining this term.

It helps to break the question into three parts:
Threat of recess appointment remains an option.
President Obama will follow his constitutional reflex and convince a viable nominee to accept.

Senate Republican's will maximize the political value of opposing a lame-duck appointment, but the uncertainty of the outcome of the presidential election will move them to the center. Uncertainty will move the Democrates toward the center, as well. Both will maximize the benefit of the opportunity, and then make a practical choice - confirmation before the scales tip more in either direction.

The Republicans will lose the Senate and fear Clinton picking a more liberal Justice. Trumpageddon will make it more difficult for the Republicans to behave as a cohesive unit against Obama toward the end of his term.

To make this prediction, I am using the "Know the power players" method from CHAMPSKNOW. In this case, I do not think that past confirmation likelihoods are as relevant because of the circumstances (otherwise, my estimate would be far higher). Here, because the appointment is contingent on presidential nomination, Senate judiciary committee recommendation, and full Senate approval, there are several key players involved and many strategic positions to consider. The first is President Obama, who has said that he will nominate someone to fill the Court's vacancy. As a political move, it may be best for him to nominate someone who he knows may not get approved so that it doesn't hurt the chances of someone who could actually get approved if nominated by the next president. It seems from the media and from statements made by Obama that he is resolute to nominate someone qualified; but beyond that, the power rests in the hands of members of the Senate and potential the presidential candidates. For these reasons, I will continue to update as the presidential election unfolds and once he nominates someone, to account for how qualified or controversial they are.
